title: Question 94

children: A 22-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a new-onset seizure and headache. She was born in El Salvador and immigrated to the United States 8 years ago. She is otherwise well and has no risk factors for HIV infection or other immunosuppressed condition. She takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Other than confusion, the examination is unremarkable.
MRI of the brain is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Seizure is the most common presentation of neurocysticercosis.
Neurocysticercosis can present with viable parenchymal cysts, calcified nonviable parenchymal lesions, intraventricular cysts, or subarachnoid cysts.
The most likely diagnosis is neurocysticercosis (
Option A
), which causes up to 30% of seizure events in endemic regions (Central and South America, India, sub-Saharan Africa). Neurocysticercosis is caused by ingesting eggs of the pork tapeworm
Taenia solium

in food or water contaminated by a human carrier of the parasite. Neurocysticercosis can present with viable parenchymal cysts, calcified nonviable parenchymal lesions, intraventricular cysts, or subarachnoid cysts. This patient has a viable parenchymal cyst with surrounding cerebral edema. Seizure is the most common presentation of neurocysticercosis. Treatment includes managing seizures and increased intracranial pressure and administering adjunctive glucocorticoids and antiparasitic agents for viable cystic lesions.
Primary central nervous system lymphoma (PCNSL) (
Option B

) initially occurs without systemic or lymph node involvement. Immunodeficiency is the most consistent risk factor, but PCNSL incidence is increasing in older, immunocompetent patients. On MRI, PCNSL appears as a single, well-demarcated, deep white matter (periventricular) lesion with minimal mass effect or edema. The patient's history and MRI findings do not support PCNSL.
Brain abscesses (
Option C

) can occur in immunocompetent or immunosuppressed persons and are most commonly seen in men. The most common predisposing conditions in immunocompetent patients include the presence of contiguous foci of infection such as sinusitis (frontal lobe) and otitis media (temporal lobe or cerebellum); hematogenous spread, often from an odontogenic process, endocarditis, or injection drug use; and following neurosurgery or trauma. Headache is the most common symptom, whereas fever is present in about half of patients, and seizure may occur in about 25% of patients. MRI may show central necrosis, ring-enhancing lesion, and edema. This patient has no predisposing condition for brain abscess or imaging features consistent with that diagnosis.
Cerebral toxoplasmosis (
Option D

) is typically found in immunosuppressed persons, including patients with HIV infection or transplant recipients. Clinical presentation includes headache, fever in approximately half of all patients, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI brain imaging reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions. This pattern is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

references: White AC Jr, Coyle CM, Rajshekhar V, et al. Diagnosis and treatment of neurocysticercosis: 2017 clinical practice guidelines by the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) and the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (ASTMH). Clin Infect Dis. 2018;66:1159-1163.
